reviewText:
Early Access Review

ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS is exactly what the title implies. You fly around in a rocket and prove to others who is the studliest of all the rockets.

Here's a Quick Look video if you want to see how this game plays. There's also my review below if you simply want a more in-depth and concise look at the game.

http://youtu.be/daoI-IMkVk0

Let me start my review by saying this game is extremely bare at this point. It only has local dogfighting between 2 rockets, 2 v 1 underdog mode, or team deathmatch. But damn is the dogfighting good. You get three different ways to attack: by shooting lasers that go straight ahead, dropping bombs that fling out your side and are effected by gravity, and finally mines that shoot out your backside and blow up behind you. Simple right? But try throwing that in with high-speed rocket action. Suddenly you have to plan your shots to cut off the path your enemy is flying. Did the enemy drop a mine? Knock it right back at him with a laser and laugh in his face. Wanna rain death on a pursuer? Fling bombs into the sky and try to weave away from the hail of death. It's simply fun experimenting and trying to become the best pilot.

And trust me, you'll always know who is the better pilot. You simply can't win the game based solely on luck. You have to dominate your opponent with the tag system they implemented. Basically put, both sides start from scratch, and if you hit the enemy 3 times in a row, it's your win. But if he hits you once, he'll knock a tag off your streak that you'll have to make up for until you fill the gauge in the top of the screen. This means games can end quickly, or be an intense test of endurance between two evenly-matched pilots.

Another great point of this game is the visuals. I love painting the cosmos with my vapor trails. Not only does it enhance the sense of speed you're getting, but it also tells the tale of the dance of death the rockets have been through. And when I say dance, I mean it. The music in this game is super catchy, too.

But let's discuss some negatives now. Just keep in mind that his is Early Access, and most of this will probably get changed in future patches.

*The game is super short in its current state (you do everything there is to do once you play your first match). It's just dogfighting. And while it's good, it might not be enough to sell it at this point for some people.
*There is no progression or anything to unlock. Something that'll keep the player coming back for more is always knowing they'll get rewarded if they play more.
*All the rockets are the same, just colored differently. I'd like to have different looking rockets just for cosmetic purposes at least. Just something to make me feel unique.
*No upgrades to weapons. I'm not talking flat out upgrades that are better than another, but more of something that makes them act differently. Like a laser that fires faster but has limited range. Or a mine that explodes in a larger radius but you can't shoot out as many. Just something to make this game more strategic and diverse would be good.
*No online. This will be fixed later, but it'll remain a negative until it's implemented.
*No tutorial. Sure it's fun flying around and getting absolutely owned by the AI for the first few times, but some sort of menu to list the controls would be nice.
*No options menu. You can't change the sound effects, resolution, or anything else ingame currently.

Now while that may be a lot of negatives, most--if not all--of those while be ironed out in the future. So wait until then if they bother you.

So to wrap this up, this game is going to bud into something very good. And for the low cost of $5 they're handing it out for currently, it certainly worth picking it up even now.

*As a side note, I will (hopefully) update this review as major patches are released or just do it again once it's finally released. Just yell at me and I'll come running to take another look if I forget.*

This game is very fun.. once you know the controls. At first I was very confused with how I controlled my rocket, thinking it was relative, but then I realized the up arrow goes up, down arrow goes down, left goes left, and right goes right. Okay, I had that figured out, but then I needed to figure out how to shoot. Space? No. Shift? No, that's a weird shield thing. Control? Nope. X? Nah. Z? Nope! D? Ah, that shoots rockets. I then started pressing WASD to see what it would do. A shoots smaller rockets, and S drops bombs.

Also, my resolution is stuck at 800x600, for some reason. This game needs an options menu, or even just a seperate executable to change the resolution.

For positive, well, the music is amazing!! This game is also very beautiful, and fast paced. It has a feel to it... It's great. And the light trails, wow. The AI is very smart, also. Still haven't won a battle.

Anyway, this is a great game, and has a lot of potential for future multiplayer, but I feel it needs a tutorial and some options.
Pick it up, though, it's worth it!

I know that this game will be also very good for the keyboard in the future, because right now it seems the developer still seems uncertain about the current controls. Hoping for the best!

Again, it's a great game, worth the money, pick it up!

I discuss: What is R3, the gameplay, music, and even the developer for those of you who are worried about Early Access.

ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS. I haven't had more fun with a game in awhile, and I have a lot of games. However, I will not make this review solely based on praising the game, but to get a better idea of what the gameplay is like I will explain all the core mechanics and aspects of the game. Pictures will not help you, you must try this out for yourself.

What is ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS?

R3 is a rocket flying arcade shooter, where you shoot rockets at other rockets.
Currently there is one single gamemode with local only, but don't let this dissapoint you. All my hours are with its smart 1v1 AI that faces a huge challenge at first. Games can go either way everytime. R3 relies on quick twitch mechanics with its easier to learn gameplay and controls. The learning curve flows very nicely where you will be able to play decently after a couple of hours, but you will always get better.

You have three weapons.
Standard Rockets(You will use this most of the time.)

Drop Rockets(These are advanced and even I have trouble using them. Many people accidentally hit themselves with it. It takes practice.)
- They drop using physics, so based off your momentum and gravity,
the rockets will drop different ways. Usually you want to use this when the enemy is far below you.

Mine(Static mine that pops out behind you.)

The neat part about R3 is its controls. They aren't relative. Up goes upward, right goes right, etc. This means you have true freedom in how you move. You can pull of neat turns and dodge obstacles at fast speeds. Hitting someone can be sometimes very difficult.
You have a shield that you activate with a button, it only comes on for about a second and will promptly dissapear. Rockets can't get through your shield but mines can. This helps prevent your uninvitable doom when faced with a barrage of rockets that you realize you can not dodge. It also gives you a little boost, and has a cooldown, so you better be careful when using it.

The standard gamemode is an advantage system. Whoever has a +3 advantage in hits wins.
Your opponent has 2 points and you hit them. They now have 1 point and you still have 0. When they are back at 0 you can now score. This gamemode influences long high octane battles, however if this sounds off to you still consider getting it as the developer plans to add more gamemodes.

Now what about the Developer!?
The lead Developer Andy Moore is probably one of the best Early Access indie devs I've seen that not only is commited to adding lots of content, but making sure everyone has an enjoyable experience. Don't be afraid that this game will not work for you, he always puts out experimental builds that you can opt into to try and listens to every complaint you have.
He's not the type of developer that goes, I like feedback

reviewText:
ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS is hands down the most entertaining way to get carpal tunnel playing couch co-op. It has beautiful aesthetics and is quite enjoyable to play with a friend, against the AI, or even in the more pacifist Zen mode flying around and making art with rocket trails. The combat is simple, intuitive, and amazing, with three projectiles and a dash maneuver which allow for diverse gameplay. You can shoot missles, leave nasty mines, and drop bombs to cause beautiful, beautiful havoc. I'm not kidding. It's quite beautiful watching the brightly colored projectiles and stages blossom with bright, cheerful explosions as your enemies spin, hit by your barrage of missles and bombs or blasted by a mine. There is a lot of potential for skill, but even beginners can play without too much barrier.

Pros:
Fun gameplay
Beautiful (minimalist) graphics
Great game modes
Couch versus, co-op vs bots, and Zen mode

Cons:
High risk of intense button mashing, play at your own risk.
No online multiplayer (and, given the intense speed of matches, it makes sense, though it would be amazing if it existed)
Basically requires a controller- playable on keyboard and mouse, but much less fun.

I highly recommend this game if you have a friend nearby or just want to relax and unwind against a bot or in Zen mode.

EDIT :

Changed from negative to positive on 3/1/2015.  Dev replied.   The devs are listening and are working on the game in a positive way, so im sure that it is headed in a good direction.  The regular game is still a thumbs down, for now, but most of my issues with it have been addressed in the beta version.

The beta version is playable for me with bloom turned off but imo its just not the same without it.
Changes included in beta version detailed at the bottom.

.............................................................................................................................................................
RECCOMENDATION :  YES :

I would wholeheartedly reccommend this game a few months ago, but not anymore.   I am writing this review with the hopes of getting the devs attentions, youve made an amazing game and I want to point out some things so that i can play it again.  I completely reccommend this game at 5$, but only after below said issues are fixed.   Review will be updated as changes happen.

Sound: 8/10
Graphics: 8/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Bloom: 2/10
Controls: 6/10
OVERALL: 6/10 for now

...............................................................................................................................................................

GAMEPLAY :


Rocketsx3 is a great PvP multiplayer game. Can be played against bots as well.  You can play upto 4 player but the experience is best with 2. You could play 4 on a TV pretty well.

You control a ship and you have 3 weapons.  Mines, missiles, and  bombs.  Each of these attacks can be fired one at a time, or charged and released to dish out a devastating barrage of your weapon of choice.

Mines launch behind you and detonate in an area after a while.  Missiles launch directly in front of you and shoot forward.     Bombs are like tiny missiles but have no thrust, so they fall off from the side of your rocket.
You get a sheild that also functions as a speed boost, allowing you to block attacks or get out of a tight situation.

First to 3 hits in a row wins! You can hit yourself and that deducts from your score.
Controlling your ship may be hard at first but youll get the hang of it.


Gameplay is fast, solid, and fluid.  Matches are usually short but may last longer. And boy are those longer matches tense.   Dodging missiles, falling for mine traps, using bombs to block your escape, a well timed charge attack to get two hits in a row or that moment when you engage eachother in a tense spiral of death.

Graphics are great, a very beautiful and neon art style, and the announcer ingame is great. A female, robotic assistant type voice.  The AI is amazing and WILL beat you many times.


................................................................................................................................................................


COMPLAINTS :

I used to love this game. I played it  everyday with a good friend of mine. Both of us have stopped playing this game now due to changes made to it over successive updates that has left the game unplayable for us.  These reasons are :

1) WAY too bright. The brightness of the ship burner and particles, as well as environment objects and trails was multiplied by 20.   There should be a slider for this.  I miss the darkened out trails that the game had in the beginning, the bright trails before the christmas update were fine too, but it became WAY too sparkly after that. no reason that this cant be optional.

2) Difficult to fight in tight spaces now.  Due to the changes to particles and brightness, when you clash with eachother in tight corners or against walls, you cant tell what is going on.

3) Unncessary clutter added.  Your health is depicted by 3 balls around your ship. I feel that this adds unncessary clutter to the game and takes away from your focus.  I prefer the healthbar at the top. No reason why this cant be an option.

4) Screen size  : I play this game on my 21 inch 1980x1080 desktop, where the game is just about playable in its current state.   On my  1366x768 laptop though, i cant see anything anymore.

5) The background was darkened out to try and fix the visibility issue i reckon,  and it looks plain terrible.

6) The pulsating rocket trail. Please no.

7) The last life slowdown. Let this be an option. It takes away from the fast paced fun of the game for me.. Totally kills the mood, although it is cool sometimes.  Could be an optional powerup or 5th button.


..............................................................................................................................................................


CONCLUSION :

Options are your best friend. Please dont just remove something and replace it with something else entirely.   Some poeple prefer one thing over another.

Online play will be coming to this game later on im sure.  On a positive note the UI work is great. Always improving. The music score is also nice.

There is no problem in the gameplay , but how the game is visually presented has totally gimped it for me and made it unplayable. If you could provide me with an older build of this game, I'd much rather play that than what is on the steam store right now.

I dont have any reviews on my account, but i care enough about this game to write this out.  Your feedback on this review would be much appreciated.  Heres hoping a dev replies or these issues are addressed.

................................................................................................................................................................


EDIT :     CHANGES IN THE BETA VERSION OF THE GAME :


The beta build of the game includes a lot of improvements, which are :

1)   A bloom and rocket trail slider.  The lowest setting in bloom is still too high for me, its the same as the regular game.  The bloom slider is overkill. http://i.imgur.com/IyQAukE.gifv

2) Tug of war is back!  But if you prefer the health bubbles, you now have bubble size, rotation speed, and distance from ship.

3) An option to enable/disable speedup/slowdown  pickups.  Though there is a bug that the pickups still appear in game, they just dont do anything.

Other misc things  and comments :   I still find the game more difficult to play than pre christmas update. Colors are brighter? The particles? I cant pin it down for sure without playing an old build again but here are my comments :

The pulsating rocket trail and environment objects distracts me.  Also, i still prefer the discolored rocket trails.   The speed boost sparks are something id want to turn off too.   In the tug of war end game timer, white on white is too difficult to see.  Its hard to tell how much time you have left, please change that.



No 1980x1080 resolution in the beta build, but thats a minor gripe.

A new gameplay feature i noticed that i DID like, is that you can now visibly see when a rocket is charging an attack. Awesome.  But instead of the white lines that indicate this, a colored outerglow or border so that its easier to see?

Progress is going well, i look forward to it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Surprisingly, while most of the optional features are missing (including a working options menu, not too big of a problem at this point) the core gameplay and look of the game is quite solid.  The input could use a little more fine tuning to increase the response time and precision, but it's mostly reliable, certainly better than a lot of games.

The big problems at the moment are that the control scheme isn't explained, and while the keyboard controls are functional, they are a bit awkward (which they acknowledge).  Also, it crashes with two players and two bots (as of 5/9/14).

However, even if you don't want to get this game now (which, for 5 bucks isn't much of a risk) keep it on your radar.  The gameplay is much more nuanced than expected.  The three different weapons don't fire in a set arc for damage, they react with physics in a fashion that adds both a layer of unpredictablility and extra utility.

For example, while you can shield a straight rocket, you can also fire more rockets at it to deflect it.  Those could then fire off in some unpredicted direction and hit another player.  Is your opponent dropping mines?  Fire a missle at the mine and bounce it in to him.  Things like that.  Straight forward, but nuanced.

A dogfight match can last anywhere between 10 seconds and 10 minutes depending on how well matched the players are, or how poorly they make decisions.  It is also quite good as a compettitive game.  Though chaotic looking, it's chaotic in the way Super Smash Bros is chaotic.  A lot is going on, but everything is based on a cause and effect system.

So if you're looking for a good local co-op game, this is one.  Online multiplayer is planned, but currently (5/9/14) unavailable.  If you prefer to play it in a more complete form, put it on your wishlist.  It is very promising, and for me, already worth a buy.

reviewText:
This is a crazy fun game featuring up to 4 Rockets shooting Missiles, Dropping bombs, and laying Mines in order to knock out the opponents 3 Bubbles(3 by default), and if you have less than the max Bubbles at the time, hitting the enemies will give you one. You can also just ram their Bubbles with your Rocket, but it's risky since at that point freaking blank range, they're practically guaranteed to hit you unless you perfectly time your Shield, which makes you invulnerable for a couple seconds.

The game is very fast pace, colorful, with great music. Music that actually makes me want to purchase its soundtrack, which is saying something since it's $8. There's also a Tug-O-War mode, were, you need to hit the other team to move the counter towards your side 3 blips, and hold it for a small-ish time, but them hitting you forces the blips towards them. And then there's Zen Mode, where you just fly around and draw pretty pictures with your Rockets Color Trail.

If you've ever seen or played Mario Carts battle mode with the 3 Balloons, the Bubbles mode is like that.

The only downside I see is that the keyboard controls greatly limit your potential, and is nowhere near as fun as it is with a Controller.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who was some fast pace arcade fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS probably has the most rockets of any game on Steam. The mechanics are simple but solid. The only officially supported game mode in this early Early Access build is one-on-one against the AI, but there's plenty more planned along the way. There's also the ability to fundamentally alter the physics and mechanics via a config file to tweak how the game is played, which is pretty neat. The graphics are basic, but are beautifully stylized and suit the game well. Flying your rocket just feels right which is a pretty crucial thing to nail.

I was initially drawn by the similarities to Gimbal, another top-down space shooter. That's about where the similarities end though. Gimbal has a variety of different parts and lets you build your own ships, all with a unique way of handling. ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS puts everyone on an equal playing field with only a few tools, focusing on individual skill. Gimbal is a very serious take on the genre, whereas ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS is as crazy and flamboyant as its art style. Both have their appeal, but ROCKETSROCKETSROCKETS is infinitely easier to pick up and play, especially on the couch for local multiplayer.

It should also be noted that you should have a controller to play this game. Keyboard controls are included, but the game is designed around the analog capabilities of the thumbstick. It's also far easier to hammer on the buttons of a gamepad to fire rapidly than on your keyboard, though you can make use of the aforementioned config file to up the fire rate of your weapons when you hold down the button.

Lastly, it's important for any Early Access game to have devs that respond to user feedback and actually work on building the game rather than using the Early Access tag as an excuse to sell something that normally would be decried for being incomplete. From my observation of the devs thus far they seem trustworthy, so nothing to worry about on that front. If the concept interests you at all, I'd definitely recommend picking this game up sooner rather than later to get in on it while it's still cheap ($5 at time of writing, $1.25 if you can snag a 75% off coupon).

reviewText:
I was initially drawn to this by just how simple yet bizarre the premise is. the idea of flying a rocket, that fires rockets at rockets while also roughly obeying rocket handling physics sounded like all of my jam. thankfully, after playing this gameafter it fully released, the game lives up to expectations.

The game has an interesting sort of light humour about it and runs very smoothly on my system, even in 4K, its graphics are simple but clean and stylised and its sound is great. but all of this would be worthless were the gameplay not there to support it.

I can gladly report that the gameplay on this titles is superb. firing rockets is tricky but getting a hit is satisfying, simply flying around requires and easy-to-learn-hard-to-master kind of skill and just how this game handles means that potential groups of up to four could have endless fun with this game. though that said, one person alone can easily find great enjoyment with this title, simply flying around in zen mode and relaxing or playing against some challenging AI.

put bluntly, the amount of skill required in this game is refreshing and its gameplay and difficulty curve will suit casual and dedicated players alike.

Finally, this game has some of the best controller support I've seen, with support for dualshock 3 and 4 controllers without ever needing any aftermarket software, naturally, Xbox support is baked in too.

all told, this is a really great game and i'm glad i played it.
